messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 56 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Structured Scene Memory for Vision-Language Navigation

Paper Abstract: Abstract Recently, numerous algorithms have been developed to tackle the problem of vision-language navigation (VLN), i.e., entailing an agent to navigate 3D environments through followingabsent{}_{\!} linguisticabsent{}_{\!} instructions.absent{}_{\!} However,absent{}_{\!} currentabsent{}_{\!} VLNabsent{}_{\!} agents simply store their past experiences/observations as latent states in recurrent networks, failing to capture environment layouts and make long-term planning. To address these limitations, we propose a crucial architecture, called Structured Scene Memory (SSM). It is compartmentalized enough to accurately memorize the percepts during navigation. It also serves as a structured scene representation, which captures and disentangles visual and geometric cues in the environment. SSM has a collect-read controller that adaptively collects information for supporting current decision making and mimics iterative algorithms for long-range reasoning. As SSM provides a complete action space, i.e., all the navigable places on the map, a frontier-exploration based navigation decision making strategy is introduced to enable efficient and global planning. Experiment results on two VLN datasets (i.e., R2R and R4R) show that our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on several metrics.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 56 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 56"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Experimental evaluation of some exploration strategies for mobile robots",
        "On evaluation of embodied navigation agents",
        "Vision-and-language navigation: Interpreting visually-grounded navigation instructions in real environments",
        "Neural machine translation by jointly learning to align and translate",
        "The Complexity of Robot Motion Planning",
        "Matterport3D: Learning from RGB-D data in indoor environments",
        "Learning to explore using active neural slam",
        "Neural topological slam for visual navigation",
        "Learning to interpret natural language navigation instructions from observations",
        "A behavioral approach to visual navigation with graph localization networks",
        "Evolving graphical planner: Contextual global planning for vision-and-language navigation",
        "Scene memory transformer for embodied agents in long-horizon tasks",
        "Speaker-follower models for vision-and-language navigation",
        "Counterfactual vision-and-language navigation via adversarial path sampling",
        "Visual simultaneous localization and mapping: a survey",
        "Neural turing machines",
        "Cognitive mapping and planning for visual navigation",
        "Towards learning a generic agent for vision-and-language navigation via pre-training",
        "Multiple view geometry in computer vision",
        "Deep residual learning for image recognition",
        "Long short-term memory",
        "Language and visual entity relationship graph for agent navigation",
        "Sub-instruction aware vision-and-language navigation",
        "Are you looking? grounding to multiple modalities in vision-and-language navigation",
        "Transferable representation learning in vision-and-language navigation",
        "Stay on the path: Instruction fidelity in vision-and-language navigation",
        "Probabilistic roadmaps for path planning in high-dimensional configuration spaces",
        "Tactical rewind: Self-correction via backtracking in vision-and-language navigation",
        "Beyond the nav-graph: Vision-and-language navigation in continuous environments",
        "Perceive, transform, and act: Multi-modal attention networks for vision-and-language navigation",
        "Rapidly-exploring random trees: Progress and prospects",
        "Gated path planning networks",
        "Self-monitoring navigation agent via auxiliary progress estimation",
        "The regretful agent: Heuristic-aided navigation through progress estimation",
        "Improving vision-and-language navigation with image-text pairs from the web",
        "An experiment in integrated exploration",
        "Listen, attend, and walk: Neural mapping of navigational instructions to action sequences",
        "Control of memory, active perception, and action in minecraft",
        "Neural map: Structured memory for deep reinforcement learning",
        "Object-and-action aware model for visual language navigation",
        "Meta-learning with memory-augmented neural networks",
        "Semi-parametric topological memory for navigation",
        "On the computational power of neural nets",
        "End-to-end memory networks",
        "Learning to navigate unseen environments: Back translation with environmental dropout",
        "Probabilistic robotics",
        "Active visual information gathering for vision-language navigation",
        "Reinforced cross-modal matching and self-supervised imitation learning for vision-language navigation",
        "Environment-agnostic multitask learning for natural language grounded navigation",
        "Look before you leap: Bridging model-free and model-based reinforcement learning for planned-ahead vision-and-language navigation",
        "Memory networks",
        "Bayesian relational memory for semantic visual navigation",
        "A frontier-based approach for autonomous exploration",
        "Neural slam: Learning to explore with external memory",
        "Vision-language navigation with self-supervised auxiliary reasoning tasks",
        "Target-driven visual navigation in indoor scenes using deep reinforcement learning"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 56 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Structured Scene Memory for Vision-Language Navigation, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
